reviewText: In reading the backside of the DVD, I was excited to watch The Lather Effect!  Unfortunately, I was bored to tears throughout it.This is about the day after a high school reunion party.  They are all in their 30's now and they show up to the reunion as they used to look.  Seems some of them came as they used to be as well - immature!They wake up at a house that is torn apart, they are all nursing hangovers - or still drunk, and they reminisce about the way things were, what happened all those years ago, etc.  They decide they need another night of the fun; which added up to pure boredom for me.Being a 30-something myself, I really thought I would love this movie.  But the music was the only thing I found myself enjoying.The cast includes Tate Donovan, Ione Skye, Eric Stoltz, David Herman, William Mapother, Connie Britton, Peter Facinelli, Sarah Clarke, Caitlin Keats, Eric Haase, Dominic Kelly, and Sarah Kelly.  The DVD also includes a commentary, a few featurettes, and deleted scenes.I cannot recommend this movie.  Unless of course you are trying to fall asleep.- 1smileycat :-)
Title: N/A

reviewText: Another tried and tested formula with a "now grown up" group revisiting their past at a reunion, but this is much better (and funnier) than "Old School" or other recent offerings.A great soundtrack of 80's classics is also well placed throughout the movie, but it's the characters, acting and emotion that really brings the movie to life.The ensemble cast may not be considered current box office stars, but there are a lot of familiar faces in this picture, not least Eric Stolz, and former child star David Herman who are hilarious, and steal each scene respectively. It's a funny picture, but it's underpinned with a message of missed opportunity, youth, revisiting old times, and even pathos at times, as each character attempts to untie the knots in there respective life paths since last they met. Old relationships are revisited, old flames fanned, and many skeletons get an airing from the closet. I felt that it was all handled with a light touch by director Sarah Kelly who manages to keep the picture moving and injects levity strategically throughout.I suspect that the people who will get the most from this movie are those that can remember the 80's and be of the same age as the characters. Some of the humor and situations may be lost on a younger viewers, and it isn't raucous or full of innuendo and cheap titillation, which in turn will probably mean it will not command a wide audience.4 stars overall. Great Movie
Title: N/A

reviewText: A word of advice to the marketers of film.  The tag-line for this movie -- used in much of the publicity and repeated on the back of the DVD case -- is: "If the '80s were the ultimate party, welcome to the hangover."  This cannot possibly have been thought to appeal to anyone who has ever had a hangover, anyone who has ever known anyone who has had a hangover, or anyone who owns a dictionary and can research what a hangover must be like to experience.  Hangovers are unpleasant; you probably don't want the audience associating your film with something unpleasant before the first reel has begun.The movie's opening scene is the aforementioned hangover.  Specifically, it's the morning after a massive reunion party where a bunch of 30-somethings trashed one of their parent's house (kindly, they threw the party just two days before the house is to be inspected for sale).  Given the effort the producers went through to decorate the set to convey the absolute madness that this party must have entailed, I was initially expecting a lot of flashbacks to the party but there were none to be seen.Gene Siskel once opined that the creators had failed if their final film was less interesting than a hypothetical documentary about the same cast and crew having lunch together.  I'd like to add a corollary to that statement.  Is this film more interesting than behind-the-scenes footage of the set designers emptying and placing beer cans and vodka bottles in every possible location?  I couldn't help but feel that showing us the party would have been much more fun than simply telling us about it.The film revolves around a group of friends looking back on their high school days, thinking about how things were, how things are now and how things could have been.  Despite the good cast, many times I simply felt that I was flipping through someone else's yearbook.  I could relate to the immediate personalities of the characters, but the actual history and backstory didn't quite come through.I think my opinion of this film can be summarized by the reaction I had when one of the 36-year-old characters says in a sad tone, "I can't believe high school is over."What?!  You...  What?!(Granted, I am slightly paraphrasing in that quote, but that is definitely the meaning behind the line.)The characters are so self-absorbed, so backward-looking that I found most of their monologues to be extremely irritating.  And after I was annoyed, I found it mildly depressing to think of people hanging on to the pettiness and silliness of events from twenty years prior.  This isn't a treatise on Faulkner's "The dead is never past"; this is simply a group of people who need a kick in the backside and an order to grow up.And I have to say that this is a  difficult film to dislike.  It's very enthusiastic.  Earnest perhaps is an adequate way of describing it.  It's got a good pace and was well produced.  The chemistry between the cast members is exceptionally good; I immediately believed that they had been friends for decades with their own interweaving, complicated pasts.  Eric Stoltz is particularly fun as the metaphorical Voice of God who dispenses wisdom and truth throughout the film.I think the main problem with the film is that it falls between two stools.  It's not an immature, raunchy, no-holds-barred fun fest.  And neither is it a mature and deep look at the way people grow and change over the years.  For an example of the latter, take the story of a character who begins the film unhappy and regretful about her life.  By the end of the film, mentally and emotionally reconciling just one event in her past completely changes her entire outlook on life.  It's too neat.This criticism of that particular plot point is reflective of other parts of the film.  The conclusion is reached far too easily.  Everything ends up tidy which just doesn't ring true given the messiness we spend the whole movie exploring.  Several threads are just forgotten about or their resolution is far too simplistic.THE LATHER EFFECT is competently made and well-acted.  It tells its story effectively.  I just happened to really dislike what the film was saying.  It's not terribly funny when it's shallow and it isn't particularly meaningful when it's deep.  It tries to do too many things at once and ends up not succeeding at most of them.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Lather Effect, you may have figured out by now, is like "The Big Chill" for Gen-Xers.  The problem is, it's not nearly as good, and I'm not just saying that because I'm a "baby-boomer".  The cast is decent - strong if not A-list.  You may recognize Tate Donovan from a number of indie films; or Ione Skye, for whom I've had a crush since "Say Anything"; Sarah Clarke, the evil Nina Myers of TV's "24"; Connie Britton (Spin City, Friday Night Lights); and of course Eric Stoltz.  So there's enough talent here - if only they were given a decent script.  The premise is similar to The Big Chill: a bunch of old school friends in their late 30's get together for a weekend at the home of two of them (twenty years on, in this case). Of course all the usual issues come up: success and failure (one character is a former child star), arrested development (Britton's character is especially conflicted concerning an old flame, selling her childhood home, and generally acting grown-up and responsible), rekindled romances, general regret and nostalgia.  There's no huge epiphany or revelation in the story, either, except a confession that's connected to the breakup of the relationship of two of the members. What made The Big Chill work was the wonderfully snappy dialog that made you laugh out loud at times, and a plot that made you care about the characters.  You get neither of that here - I don't think I even chuckled once during this film.  I also found the characters self-centered and annoying, especially Stoltz's character, who speaks in some weird affected accent ("Valley Boy?") and rattles off non-significant bon mots, especially his theory that's the basis for the title - and even that doesn't amount to much.  Yeah, the soundtrack is pretty cool, especially if you cut your teeth on early MTV, but a soundtrack CD will fulfill that need.  In summary, don't waste your money buying it, think twice before renting, and if you're really insistent on seeing it, wait till it's on the free movie channel.

No.  Is there reasonable acting  No.

reviewText: Be careful of anything calling itself... "a Big Chill for a new generation", or "suspense worthy of Hitchcock" or anything relating itself to something that was already done previously and most likely done better.I wasn't a big fan of "The Big Chill", but I know there was one thing about it that "THE LATHER EFFECT" failed to do; make you care about the characters. The movies first mistake was its premise to begin with. Why on earth producers and studios keep funding movies that obviously have nothing 'new' to bring to the table or its only redeeming factor is that it's LIKE something that has already been done? I don't get it.It was cheaply done. Poor camera shots with no intent to correct lighting. Amateur mistakes like shooting somebody who is standing in front of a large sunlit window or just settling with a dark outside gathering and or a dark bedroom rather than lighting them better.All that aside, THE LATHER EFFECT, is just plain forgettable and time consuming. It's almost like going to a high school reunion and then realizing that you didn't go to that school and don't know any of these people. They're talking about things that you never took part in and people that you never knew and they never even attempt to rectify that.That being said, you're better off spending time with your REAL FRIENDS than watching this movie. Call your friends up, play some cards, have a yard party, have a barbecue and don't waste 94 minutes with this one.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Obviously, in the minority but I enjoyed The Lather Effect. Twenty years after graduating from high school, a group of former classmates meet for a "come as you were" party. Inevitably, the group comes upon unresolved issues, and unfulfilled dreams. The cast is good enough, particularly Caitlin Keats, who's beautiful and sexy. The Eric Stoltz character does stand out, but not in a good way. I know he's supposed to be the drunk bad boy, but I just found him an annoying loser.My main problem with the movie is that a secret is revealed in such an anticlimactic way that it's hard to really feel the effects it had on the characters -- even if the actors weep and pout as a consequence. And the resolution between the torn lovers is just ridiculous. Come on, no one decides someone is not his/her soul mate based on such stupidity.Other than that, it's an OK movie. I'd just delete the "waiting for Cameron Crowe" featurette, which makes the director look like a moron at best and a stalker at worst.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Now you'll have to take this review with a grain of salt....I graduated high school during this time period so for me it was a fun movie. I enjoyed the whole premise of having a "come as you were" party, where they all dressed up in 80's garb.  If you are younger than your mid thirties/early 40's you probably will think they over exaggerated the weird costumes, but alas, the million black rubber bracelets, chunky crosses, leggings with skirts, lace gloves and big hair....sadly true.The soundtrack is fun.  Lots of the hits that you listened to during the time. I kind of felt like I was with my own group of friends waxing a little nostalgic for the simpler times before life in general got harder.The premise?  Well, it is a "come as you were 80's party" that is being held at the childhood home of one of the old 80's gang.  She is at the home of her parents as they are away as someone needs to be there as they are selling the house and the walk-through is happening in a couple days.  Good time for a party right?  Um, yeah, I didn't say it was a believable plot, but a good time, absolutely.  The house of course gets totally trashed, secrets are revealed and everyone leaves a bit more satisfied with their lives as they are.This would be a movie for those that came of age in the 80's and just want a fun movie.  Nothing deep here, just a good time and a bit of nostalgia.The extras are nothing exciting so I wouldn't bother with those, but the movie was suprisingly, much better than I had expected.

reviewText: A very light hearted 30-something drama that feels a bit like you just walked into these people lives.Well acted, funny but I found a certain plot point unrealistic that no one had figured it out over 20 years. It was also confusing as to who's house they were in until closer to half way through the film which I felt was a missed oportunity for more humor.Eric Stolz cracked me up and I did for the most part find the characters believeable but for that one big plot mistake I think this would have been a 4 star film.Enjoyable and worth watching, the soundtrack is also fun.

reviewText: I would much rather have had the actors improvise, as the written lines of dialogue in this film were what I found to be the most unoriginal, unexciting cheese one could ever imagine.  I can't believe the actors appearing in the film didn't drop the script and run when they did a read through.  Maybe they did, and this is the 2nd or 3rd set of actors they had to use!  Who knows, but I can't believe the senseless drivel I had to sit through watching this.Right from the opening scene, which was way overdone, with all the debris from the morning after of the 80's reunion party.  I think someone could party for one month straight and still be hard pressed to leave as much of a disaster area as the filmmaker's portrayed this house and yard.  In fact, the rest of the scenario involving these people is as believable as the rubbish shown on the property.All the way around, this is one of the worst films I've ever seen.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you grew up during the 80s (like me!), this is an almost must-see film.  It's about a group of high school friends who meet up 20yrs after the fact for a wild party.  Of all the times to trash a house, they do it 2 days before the house is to be inspected by potential buyers.  Sounds like a recipe for disaster!The home belongs to Valinda (Connie Britton), and she is very depressed about how she can't seem to let go of her happy-go-lucky high school days.  In fact, the house itself is a sort of symbol for her having to let go of her former self and move on.  In many ways, this movie reminded me of a sort ofSt. Elmo's Fire20 years later.For myself, I could very much relate to the characters as I'm roughly the same age;  pushing 40, doing the mid-life crisis thing and occasionally looking back upon the "good old days."  While I wouldn't rank my days in HS as the best days of my life, things did seem a whole lot simpler back then.If you're a sucker for nostalgic films (like me!), then this one is a big-time  must for your DVD collection.  The soundtrack is all 80s songs, some of which I had not heard for the better part of 20yrs.  For those of us who grew up during the 80s, it's sometimes beneficial to take a look back, and then move on.  This story will help you do just that.

Title: N/A

reviewText: Do NOT let it's DVD cover fool you, this was a heart-felt tale of a group of grown-up Generation Xers (that means:in their late 30's now), getting together again for one more weekend of old-time partying and laughs. Think of it as "The Big Chill" for the "Me" generation. Nice acting by middle-of-the-road actors like Connie "Friday Night Lights" Britton, William "Lost" Mapother, Ione "Say Anything" Skye (where the Heck has she been?) and Eric Stoltz, among others. Pretty much what you'd expect, with it's longing of high school's past, regretful past decisions, and the fear of having to accept that the party truly is over, I found myself at first rolling my eyes at it's possible parody of representing my own generation until the dialogue began and I felt like they were like my own friends of the 80's caught on videotape. While I would NOT suggest this film to anyone under the age of thirty (sorry kids, you won't get it), anyone above that that can fully remember when Madonna was sexy, hair was at least five inches above your scalp, AND are currently today looking at mortgages, raising kids, and wondering where all the time went, will definitely enjoy this film. A nice little surprise treat of a movie.(RedSabbath Rating:8.5/10)
summary: If You Can Remember Parachute Pants, Get This Movie NOW!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was not expecting Oscar-quality acting from the cast, but I recognized many of the actors from other television series and had set some level of expectation. I was not disappointed, although some of the plot and dialogue did seem extremely predictable. Perhaps it is due to the large selection of "high school nostalgic recollection" movies out in the market. This movie isn't horrible, it is just more of the same and is easy for those in the late 20s to early 40s demographic to identify.The director wastes no time in getting to the thick of the story. The movie begins in the aftermath of a huge "debauchery" of a party, and the characters begin to trickle in. The movie ends almost as suddenly as it begins, and I feel that the director's hint at the end (regarding a potential cycle of high school hijinks with the new family that moves in) is going to be lost on some viewers as it is too subtle.Overall, I give The Lather Effect 4/5 stars because it is rather enjoyable and has an actual story to tell. However, it is far from unique and I found myself bored to tears in certain scenes. I enjoyed Sarah Clarke's portrayal of Nina in "24" so I am probably going to be a little biased in this review.
summary: Great ensemble, enjoyable plot, slow delivery
Title: N/A

reviewText: "The Lather Effect" isn't a typical three star-rated movie,insofar as it went from trying to be a "A 'Big Chill' for Generation X!,"  as the banner across the front of the DVD case extolled, to being a credible movie about never being able to go back and relive those days of ones youth.The cast, consisting of Connie Britton, Sarah Clarke, Tate Donovan, Peter Facinelli, David Herman, Caitlin Keats, William Mapother, Ione Skye and Eric Stoltz, were strong enough for this movie, but they never quite lifted it from being an "B" feature, because it was trying too hard to be "The Big Chill," and a couple of other movies, such as "Risky Business," et. al., but just didn't try to build on itself for the first 30 minutes.Then, David Herman, as Corey, the "famous" one of the lot, makes a revelation that upends the dynamics of the group, and Connie Britton and William Mapother, as star-crossed lovers, are drawn together, again, and the other characters settled-down and build on themselves, as they are, rather than what they used to be.The "Lather Effect," an "effect" that was explained as when the second application of shampoo is used (you know, shampoo, rinse and re-apply shampoo) the lather is thicker.... which, somehow, never worked out that way for me... I always thought it was just a way the shampoo folks had for getting you to use twice as much shampoo, but I digress.  Give "The Lather Effect" a watch, but don't let the first 30 minutes defer you from a decent movie.  Had the first 30 minutes been stronger, I would have given this movie four stars.
summary: "The Lather Effect" is Deja Vu all Over, Again
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was a pleasant movie that showcased some interesting characters and dropped them in a bit of a contrived situation. However, it was not "The Big Chill" for those of us graduating school in the 80's. I'll grant you that there were some interesting choices made with characters, such as Eric Stolz's, in that he was not supposed to be a contemporary of the rest of the cast, but rather a bit older and a bit of a joke even when they'd been in school and yet now he'd reached a point where he was accepted by the "gang". I liked that the women who had the hots for the stud way back when didn't go forward with meeting him, because you can't go back and it made a point of that.On the whole, though, it just seemed a bit light. It wasn't as deep or meaningful as it could have been. There was much ground they could have covered with the characters, such as Peter Facinelli's - the kid brother who they all believe is selling dope out of the basement - but it just wasn't mined.Good, but not a full meal - so to speak.
summary: Cute movie, but not "The Big Chill" for the 80's
Title: N/A

reviewText: It's the day after an all-out Pali High reunion bash held at the home of one of the revelers, and so bring on the wicked, wicked hangovers. THE LATHER EFFECT opens up with longtime friends regrouping the morning after to chow down on deli cold cuts and to further reminisce. Lots of things to clean up and air out, as the party has left an indelible mark, not only on the ruined house itself but also on the participants. THE LATHER EFFECT is a dramedy of old friendships and lingering heartbreaks and nagging regrets, and there's lots and lots of talking. And, since this premise isn't exactly new, you probably already know where it's all heading.The story centers on nine familiar characters, all thirty-somethings, all with issues crying out to be resolved, all clinging to the past (excepting Tate Donovan's practical, quasi-stuffy character). These cats are fine and dandy on the surface, but mostly messed up underneath. The actors, a cast of B-listers and unknowns, do a fine job fleshing out their characters, and it's not their fault that the story is unoriginal and the script mostly waterlogged with uninspired dialogue and telegraphed twists. THE LATHER EFFECT didn't keep me on the edge of the sofa, didn't make me go "Oh, snap!" - although I was mildly curious as to how things would turn out for several of the supporting characters, particularly the stunning, brainy, and promiscuous Katrina (Caitlin Keats) and the restless housewife Claire (Sarah Clarke, of 24). Eric Stoltz, who affects a surfer dude accent, walks away with the most interesting role honors, closely followed by Caitlin Keats (who is so sexy I'm very surprised she hasn't done more films). The central characters, I didn't care for as much. This suggests something uncomplimentary about the film.THE LATHER EFFECT falls somewhere in the middle of the pack. I certainly didn't mind watching it, but it wasn't like I had my eyeballs glued to the screen, absentmindedly wolfing down popcorn. I wouldn't call it an insightful film, but it does strive to be an honest one. There are several good moments here (though not enough), some well done scenes involving these friends simply hanging out or in full shindig mode. There are fine scenes of barefaced confessions and throwaway truths. One sweet example happens during a party game, as the younger-than-the-others Danny disarmingly narrates how he lost his virginity in high school to a college girl, and, yes, it involves one of these women present. Another one is the Eric Stoltz character's perceptive breakdown of how to win the beauteous Katrina, always available but ever unattainable (trust me, it makes sense in the film). But my favorite bit has to be the gang rocking out in the living room to Dr. Sauce's "Swamprat." This film is a collection of little moments - most of which are ordinary enough, but some, revelatory  - all making up a day in the life. By the end of the movie, it's understood that these old and unhappy friends have gained some measure of closure and a better understanding of whatever ails them. That's fine.And, yes, the soundtrack, as touted, is pretty rad.
summary: Okay, the soundtrack is pretty good...

reviewText: If you're a child of the 80s, and ever waxed nostalgic for Risky Business, remember when Madonna was edgy and fresh, and would see anything by John Hughes, this is a must see.  You can't go back, but you can reminisce.  The premise is a "come as you were" party celebrating 80s pop culture, and music, but it's really about those of us in the post-baby boomer, not really Gen X generation and the lives we've led.  Enjoyable performances and chock full of 80s references.  I saw it SXSW, wanted to see it theatres again, but at least it's now in my DVD collection.
summary: Come as you were... the morning after

reviewText: The question is not if a film is as good as or better than another one.  The question is not if we could be watching a better film.  In almost every case, I assume the answer would be YES but we might have less than twenty films to watch.  I feel the question should be "Is this an enjoyable film?"  I find the answer for this film is "Yes".  The actors are all good solid talents in believable roles.  The situations are plausible and some of the lines are good.  You will smile, laugh and maybe get nostalgic.  Is this a great film?  No but how many great films are their?
summary: This film can stand on its' own

reviewText: Now I suppose as far as "B" movie's go this one isn't all that bad, but if you're looking for the next best thing in stoner/high school reunion movies look else where.  Basically the plot of the movie is a bunch of old high school pals (now middle aged) get together to have a reunion party.  The rest of the movie is basically after party clean-up & reminissing about the good old days.  It was really all a bunch of over dramatic "BS".  This might work out okay as a chic flick maybe I guess, but the guys best steer clear.  I guess I kinda expected this one to be funny too & unfortunately it really wasn't.  I don't know what I really expected though judging the ensemble cast of washed out, has been  actors.  Tate Donavan, hey pal, you were great in "Cuffs" (anyone remember that one? :P) & "Ghost", but it might be time to hang it up now buddy.  About the only thing this movie has going for it is the sound track & again like another reviewer's already said that might be a bad sign if the cover of the movie is using that to promote rather than the movie itself.  All in all, I can't say I'd ever go out of my way to see this again, it wasn't the worst movie in the world, but there are far, FAR better out there.

reviewText: Imagine the dreams you had in high school of making movies about - well - life in high school after you got out of high school.Sarah Kelly and Tim Talbott have acheived their dream, which for viewers of this banal, trite 95 minute movie is a nightmare.The movie opens on a house where a reunion of an 80's high school class was held the night before. The premise that a party could produce so much debris, particularly the truckloads of beer kegs and alcohol bottles is ridiculous. The whole set is ridiculous. The few party attendees who spent the night set to clean the place up - the house is due to be inspected the next day prior to its sale.The stories of the men and women are supposed to tug on our hearts as their life stories come tumbling out. Frankly, they're all self-centered losers who fail to engender any sympathy. None of their dramas are significant or engaging.The soundtrack music is good - and that's the only aspect of this dud that is.Jerry

Title: N/A

reviewText: Fun little film. Well done homage to "The Big Chill," (you will notice many similarities) with a group of Gen Xers getting together for a high school reunion in their 30's. (Must be a 15 year reunion, because 20 years would put them closer to their 40s, unless they all graduated young. It has more the feel of a 20 year than a 10 year reunion about it, however.) We don't see the actual reunion, as the action begins the "morning after," complete with hangovers and "oh my god, did she really do that?!" situations. It captures very well the kind of nostalgia and behavior reunions like this can involve (for any generation, I might add). It also captures human behavior in all its silliness, pain, warmth, and joy.The music is vintage 80s and very good. It's also cool to see real vinyl records again. Great ensemble cast makes the characters and their interactions believable. The dialog is honest, sexy, funny, and about as realistic as a movie can be. There is no nudity or sexual activity (unless you count kissing), but plenty of frank sexual talk about sexual activity and swearing. There is also drinking and drug use, so be advised.It stands up well on multiple viewings, and the "making of" extras add a lot to the feel of the film. I liked it.Oh, and by the way, there IS no greatest song of all time...........

reviewText: Tate Donovan, Eric Stoltz, Ione Skye and Connie Britton head up a decent cast in "The Lather Effect," a mild comedy where friends gather for a "Come As You Were" 80's party and wake up to find themselves older and still dealing with the past.  While cleaning up Britton's home, the group remembers the old days, mistakes made, what if's, good things, old flames, etc.  Some of them can't see beyond their pasts while others have firmly gripped their current lives and prepare for the future.  As the group divides into various sized smaller groups, the film cuts between all of them as they talk.....a lot.  What you have in the end is a somewhat depressing remembrance of days long gone mixed in with a few comedic moments.Stoltz, although he plays the older "party crasher" guy, holds this tale together as the voice of wisdom.  He seems to be channeling a little bit of his stoner character from "Fast Times At Ridgemont High."  Tate Donovan does a good job as the "serious" one.  The rest of the group fills in the normal stereotypes:  the easy girl, the person holding onto the past, the little brother, the good girl with marital problems, etc., etc.  To top it all off, you have a former child star thrown into the fray.The cover of the DVD boasts an "awesome soundtrack" that really is pretty awesome.  However, when a film brags on the strength of its soundtrack on the front of the DVD case, that should be a warning that this film may not necessarily be the greatest thing around.Deleted scenes, forgettable documentaries and audio commentary make for your average special features.In short, you'll love the music that plays throughout this film.  You'll laugh at some of it, maybe even recall old memories, but in the end you get nothing but a ho-hum comedy that could have been so much better.  Recommended as a rental.

reviewText: It's not often I have trouble finishing a movie, but this one just did not interest me at all.  I thought I'd like it because the cast contains many actors I like (Connie Britton, Eric Stoltz, Tate Donovan).  And they were okay, but there's not much they can do with a boring story.Not recommended.
Title: N/A

reviewText: A bunch of hung-over thirty-somethings wake up after a big reunion party; the house is trashed, they're wasted, all they want to do is talk about who did what to whom twenty years ago, and so they decide to make another night of it.If you saw "The Big Chill," you know what this movie is about - endless reminiscing about the good old days, backed up by a rock soundtrack. In this low-budget movie, however, none of the characters is likeable or memorable; they all act like wallowing pigs and it's off-putting to say the least.  The wonderful Eric Stoltz is the biggest name in the cast, but sadly, he doesn't make much of an impression here.  The dialogue sounds like it was improvised and does feels real, but it gets boring after a while and, as one character says, "You're too busy living in the past to know how good you've got it today."The soundtrack is made up of songs I've never heard of, but if you have, you'll probably like them.  I thought the commentary and "Making of" extras were better than the movie, which was a drawn-out ode to  debauchery.  A vanity project for the writer/director, this movie may hit home with some viewers, but I couldn't relate to any of the spoiled, foul-mouthed characters.  I wanted them to grow up.  Now.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "The Lather Effect" is not a great movie, but it's not a terrible one either, and it improves as it goes along.  At first the characters seem like a depressingly immature bunch, but they become more likeable and interesting as the story proceeds.Corey (David Herman) is probably the most interesting character, and ultimately proves to have been the catalyst for several of the other characters' main regrets in life.  Certainly the movie's finest moment comes when Jack (William Mapother) expresses his forgiveness of Corey by asking him to play air drums during the rendition of "Swamp Rat".On the other hand, what we learn near the end of the movie about Mickey (Eric Stoltz) makes him perhaps the film's most admirable character.  Stoltz, who also served as the movie's associate producer, is one of those actors who have never become huge stars despite appearing in so many movies that almost everyone has seen at least one of them.  He's clearly having a lot of fun with his role here, and even gets to deliver the dialogue explaining the film's title.But "The Lather Effect" is not without flaws.  The final revelation about Valinda (Connie Britton) comes as no surprise and is probably the most cliched possible ending for her storyline.  The excursion to the police station is harmful to the film's unity of place; the climactic scene between Valinda and Jack at the baseball field less so.  Valinda's husband Will (Tate Donovan) unconvincingly becomes more sympathetic toward the end of the movie (or, to be more charitable, demonstrates a more sympathetic side of his character), seemingly only because the plot requires that the audience be happy for Valinda to stay with him.All in all, "The Lather Effect" is no "Breakfast Club".  On the comedy quality scale, it's not even superior to an average episode of "Murphy Brown" or "Two and a Half Men".  But it is heartfelt and harmless fun.
summary: "How can you have no connection at all to your past?"
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was really looking forward to this movie, billed as a "Big Chill" for those who went to high school in the 80's.  I did attend high school in the  80's, but found that the only part of this movie I could really relate to is the music.The movie opens the day after a monster "Come as You Were" party that, from the detritus, reminded me of the house parties that were the staples of 80's coming-of-age flicks.  Unfortunately, I think I would rather have seen the party itself than the aftermath.  I couldn't really relate to any of these people who seem to want to go back to high school instead of returning to their lives after their reunion.  The actors' performances were great, but the story was dull, dull, dull.The music was great, even though most of the songs were just background fragments, lasting five seconds.  The music, not the characters and their endless conversation, made me feel nostalgic.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I can imagine the meeting where this screenplay was pitched: think of it as a Big Chill for the 80s generation, great soundtrack and a hard-hitting look at a generation.  If only someone had said, "well guys the Big Chill wasn't (in retrospect) all that great a movie and the 80s generation doesn't quite provide the same hook as the 60s so why are we doing this exactly?"  That question would have helped saved 90 minutes or so of my time that I'll never get back.What we have here is a mini high school reunion.  Old flames are rekindled, old random hook-ups are remembered fondly, and new ones are applauded.  Then there is the requisite angst about life choices, career choices and the like.  The only problem is that at the center of the angst, at the center of the let's get it on like we did when we were kids chatter is a series of vacuous characters who had no appeal to me at all.  So their angst didn't become my angst, rather it became my annoyance.The soundtrack was decent to be sure and that was the only thing about the movie that caused me to watch it all the way through.  My reccomendation: buy the soundtrack or turn on a classic rock radio station and skip the movie.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Val (36) throws one last party at the house where she grew up.  It's being sold by her parents and it's the last chance for everybody she grew up with in the 80s to get together and get really drunk and silly while they reminisce about their high school days.This movie is the "C" version of the Big Chill.  The chacters were very one-dimensional and acting was spotty at best - what was up with Eric Stoltz doing an effected english accent?  It was a character, I know, but since he co-produced it I thought he would have come up with much better.There were high school soul mates that were broken apart on purpose but have moved on with their lives, two woman who realize they shouldn't let a man interfer with their friendship, and moving on from the past.  All between drinking games, pot smoking philosophies and "truth or dare" - which REALLY isn't as interesting as it sounds.  The morning after the party, the house was a complete wreck just like in high school.  None of the characters seemed like they had matured much even if they were tagged doctors, mothers, etc.If you are looking for 80s nostalogia, this movie might be for you but only if you have nothing better to watch.  It works best for those who still live in their parents basement and lament over the good old days.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie touts itself as "a `Big Chill' for Generation X".  Sorry, but that film has substance, poignancy and a great stellar cast.  All this "film" has is one recognizable name, Eric Stoltz and he's forty- seven - not exactly in his thirties.  But that's being petty, like this film, so I'd have to simply describe it as one big hangover than never gets cured.  The entire premise is one last party amongst friends at a house that just happens to be on the market to be sold the next day.The first scene is the heroine waking up in her bed, hung-over and as she rolls over, she finds a used condom.  Welcome to the plot.  The rest of the film consists of various party members pulling themselves together and talking about the night before.  The house is so overly party damaged that it looks like a big cartoon.  Bras, clothing, beer kegs, adult toys, booze bottles, empty pizza boxes and anything else that the crew could toss in is everywhere.  It looks more like the entire college campus had the party in that one house.  It is overdone.For the less than a dozen or so actors, the dialogue is common, pedestrian, boring, juvenile and malignant.  There is simply no connection between characters nor is there a single moment that is humorous.  The language is foul.  Not that that is a problem, other than it is simply foul to be foul.  No relevance.  I found this film to be actually painful to watch.  Some of the conversations try to speak of meaningful moments from the past, but they are petty and adolescent.  None of the conversations go in any meaningful direction.  There is simply a beginning, a middle part and an end and none of it satisfies.  A minor soundtrack is attached for a little ambience, but it's too little too late and it never even made it to a compact disc.  They called this, "The Lather Effect" and that seems appropriate, as when I was done watching this debacle of a money-waster, I felt like I needed a long shower.To use a quote:  "I can eat a can of Kodak and puke a better movie." -- Kim Novak in The Mirror Crack'd
Title: N/A

reviewText: The idea billed in the promotional materials for this movie was a high school reunion in the form of a "come as you were" monster party. Instead, the viewer of the movie is treated to the small "after party" beginning with the formulaic hang-overs followed by interactions with the 9 characters depicted on the box. Even more weird is the fact that some of the characters in "The Lather Effect" appear to embody the "come as you were" in appearance while others do not: Peter Facinelli looks like Tom Cruise from the scene in Risky Business dancing around in his briefs; William Mapother (who, incidentally is Tom Cruise's cousin) is dressed like Don Johnson from "Miami Vice;" Tate Donovan is dressed in such a way as to resemble Anthony Michael Hall's character fromSixteen Candles (High School Reunion Collection)now all grown up."The Lather Effect" just can't figure out what kind of movie it wants to be: a coming of age story? a nostalgia film? a mockery of people who live in the past?As a result, the actors performances suffer. David Herman's character, while mildly enjoyable is too uneven; Connie Britton's character is uninteresting and lacks depth; other than wondering whether Mapother's character is dresses like Don Johnson all the time or only for this occasion you don't care one way or the other for him; Ione Sky's character is simply not believable. It is only the intervention of Eric Stoltz character (ironically) providing the "wisdom" of the movie and Tate Donovan's character infusing a slight bit of "reality" is the movie rescued from the doldrums.The soundtrack is awesome even if the use of music in the movie is underwhelming. It is 95 minutes of fluff... no more... no less

reviewText: Sweet Jesus what was I thinking?  I forced myself to watch this thing essentially twice... because I fell asleep both times.  Sadly, I should relate to the characters, but the only thing of interest here was trying to figure out where I have seen the actors before.  A virtual who's who of "who"?  Oh yeah, the guy from MadTV, oh ... that [...] from 24, oh... Eric Stolz... in plenty of movies, and the only one I can think of is "Mask"....  oh... and that cute guy with a nice butt in leather jeans in that car show that got cancelled... etc.Ok, well that was the first five minutes.Basically a bunch of people too old to remember anyone from High School, but meet anyway, and screw because they'll take anything they can get at this point.  Honestly, I kept dozing off and waking up when I heard Billy Idol... and then again saying "is that Night Ranger"? ... and then remember the Spishack Infomercial "Dentist in a Box" in the middle of a heartfelt moment.Worst. Review. Ever....but, sorry, I cannot attempt to watch this again.  One star for Billy Idol.  Another for reminding me of Night Ranger.

reviewText: The Lather Effect attempts to pull us into the "after" party of a RETRO 80s RAGER.  We are introduced to a few characters as they struggle through their intial hang-overs and eventual hair of the dog next day drinking. In between this we are given glimpses at their characters through some snappy and some not so snappy dialogue.  For a film that is all about remembering the thankfully bygone era of the 80s, there is little nostalgia on display other than the costumes and the soundtrack, (which really just teases us with snippets of the songs for the most part.)The actors do their best here,(David Herman stands out) and it is far from unwatchable but one gets the feeling eventually that this was a bit of a squandered effort.The forced character realizations near the end come one after another and finally end up feeling flatter than the beer in the leftover kegs that litter the scenery.  As the RZA says in his brief cameo appearance "next time invite me to the party", my thoughts exactly as the night before looked like alot more fun.  The DVD extras are decent and there is a *gasp* CHAPTER INSERT, now thats nostalgic.  Mildly recommended as rental, or you could just watch some John Hughes movies,  thats the 80s I remember.
summary: The bubbles will build up on you
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Lather Effect starts off with the camera panning throughout a house following a reunion party of less than a dozen folk.Unfortunately, if those people consumed all the alcohol bottles shown, they'd all be in the hospital with acute alcohol poisoning.And that was the start.The Lather Effect refers to the instructions on many bottles of shampoo: use, rinse, repeat.  That second lather is even frothier than the first.  So... expect that party following a party to be richer and wilder.In other words, people with hangovers are worse at keeping their feelings and secrets to themselves than those who are simply drunk.New people connect, old flames are new flames, and current flames are renewed or extinguished.Well, that about wraps up the film.  I know there will be comparisons with The Big Chill but, believe me, this one is in a different league.  And it's not the majors.
summary: Reunion flick, but this one won't be a classic...
Title: N/A

reviewText: I love the Big Chill and was very excited to see an updated version. The Lather Effect is the story of a group of thirty-somethings, who were best friends in high school getting together for a reunion party.  I have to admit that I was put off right from the start when I saw how trashed the house was. I don't know many people in their thirties that would trash their houses like that.  It has a great cast but I found that for the most part we never learned enough about the characters.By the end we knew and cared more but it came so late in the movie that it was a disappointment.  I did love the music. Eric Stoltz's character was the most interesting one and I loved Katrina's pink dress :-).Fine if you're looking for a lightly entertaining movie.
summary: Thank goodness for Eric Stoltz and the pink dress
Title: N/A

reviewText: For once the description on this product is correct - this is every bit an attempt to make THE BIG CHILL for the 80s generation.  The film lacks CHILL's polish and maturity, but it isn't without its merits.The ensemble cast has gathered for a reunion/party.  I say HAS gathered, because we start the film smack in the middle of this reunion weekend.  The first morning after, as it were.  As such, the film has a bit of a rocky start as characters refer to events that just happened last night, rather than us actually seeing them happen.  The characters, then, are hard to sympathize with, because we feel like latecomers to the drama "already in progress."The opening third of the film basically wastes ALOT of time with the crew talking, making unnecessarily lewd jokes, and whining about how they can't go back to high school.  The lead character, Valinda, seems particularly stuck in the past.  Her husband, thankfully, finally begins to show signs of realizing that the party was fun and all, but its time to clean up and get back to being responsible again.  But, Valinda and cast continue to reminisce and decide to let the party continue for a second night.FINALLY in the last act do we start to learn some of the hidden secrets that are the root of these wistful feelings.  The final portion of the story goes a long way toward bringing the film back on track as Valinda, her husband, and one of the other couples suddenly realize they have an important issue to tackle that will allow all of them to continue with their lives without constantly wondering "what could have been."Whereas BIG CHILL dealt with the process of growing older and taking on responsibility, LATHER focuses more on revisiting past choices and exploring what might have changed.  I think in the end there is a good lesson about not getting wrapped up in the past.People will have different reactions to this movie based on their opinion of their own high school experience.  Those who really enjoyed high school may do well to explore this myth of nostalgia with these characters.  Those who abhorred that period of their lives (like myself) will more likely identify with Valinda's husband, telling the rest of the crew that they are nuts for wanting to "go back."Whatever your reaction, you will find that the film is well-acted (for the most part) and well staged.  My only complaint is that the front end is too long with repetitive conversations.  I'd have rather gotten to know more about some of the other characters.However, I also think this film represents a serious missed opportunity in that this would have been a GREAT project to reunite the original 80s Brat Pack (Anthony Michael Hall, Molly Ringwald, Judd Nelson, Ally Sheedy . . .) Perhaps they tried to make it happen, I don't know, but I couldn't help but think how much more interesting the movie would have been with them in it.  Much more nostalgiac and meaningful.The film is not rated, but would definitely have been rated R for strong language and ongoing sexual anecdotes.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I like slice-of-life comedy/dramas quite a bit. This movie falls into that type of category; low-key, lots of dialogue, characters learning a bit about themselves as well as each other.  The trouble is, despite some nice performances, the movie really left little impression on me.  The story, what little there is, centers on a group of friends in their late-30s trying to relive a little of their '80s-era glory days.  The movie begins the morning after a big '80s-nostalgia themed party.  The various participants have been friends for years. Clearly these people are resisting the aging process and the possibility (probability, in fact) that the time has come to grow up.  Everyone is hung over, either from drinking or other substances (or a combination).  They sit around, while ostensibly cleaning up the trashed house, and talk about the old days.The biggest strength of the movie is it's ensemble cast - some of whom you are likely to know by name (Eric Stolz in particular, possibly Ione Skye) while others will undoubtedly be familiar (William Mapother, for instance). The dialogue has an easy-going, relaxed feel.  The trouble for me was that none of the characters were especially likable, no matter how convincingly portrayed.  They came across as self-indulgent jerks, for the most part.  No emotional investment developed over the course of the movie.The soundtrack - highly touted on the DVD cover - is comprised of '80s hits.  It is indeed an impressive collection of various radio classics from that era.  But when the soundtrack is the best part of a movie, something is fundamentally wrong.
Title: N/A

reviewText: We see a lot of movies. A good chunk of the movies we see are independent; small is usually better in the industry. Well, not in this case.As others have said, the box touts a "come as you were" party for mid 80's grads. Being two mid-80's grads, we were looking forward to the fun. But the movie starts with the hangovers & we don't even get to see everyone's "were."  It' s as if it starts in the middle. Watching this is akin to going to your new boy/girl-friend's reunion & sitting around listening to everyone talk about people you don't know.Some of the performances are passable, most are bad. Eric Stoltz is embarrassing. He should be further embarrassed because he helped produce it. (We were wondering if they just filmed the whole thing in his house on the cheap). All of these 36 year olds act like 16 year olds...only in really boring ways.The premise and much of the "business" given to the actors makes no sense (why would you scrub the grout of the bathroom with a toothbrush when there are bigger messes all around you to pick up?) The co-writer was a staff writer for South Park, so you would THINK that there would be something remotely funny here. You'd be thinking wrong.What JBizzle said...get the soundtrack if you're feeling nostalgic...get this if you have insomnia. This is about as much like "The Big Chill" as "Ernest Scared Stupid" is like "Silence of the Lambs."
summary: Not even worth a rental, from the library, for free...
Title: N/A

reviewText: As my title says this film is a typical case study of a group of friends reuniting after spending x amount of years apart.Everyone has a group of high school friends.  The people you spent 8 hours a day, 5 days a week with.  The ones whom shaped who you became as a person.  And the ones that always told you to follow your dreams.  The people that are always a crystal cream picture of yourself unjaded and ready for anything the world could possible send you.Fast forwards 20 years and those 4 years of test cramming, first kisses, and literal lessons have all become nothing but the past.  A couple of collective memories of empowerment and like everything was under control.And this is the basis of this movie.  A group of high school friends want to reunite 20 years after there graduation date.  But instead of being reminded of how the years have aged them, they want to truly have a night of forever young.  So they all come to a party just like they were 20 years ago in 1987.And like any good "time of your life" film: secrets are revealed, lost lovers reunited, and life lessons are truly learned.  The film isn't the greatest, but it isn't the worse either.  It has its moments of sappy genus, and then moments of pure cheese.But if you feel like a nostalga trip and an excuse to remember Lori Hodgens and David Hilbert - than this movie might be worth checking out.
Title: N/A

reviewText: THE LATHER EFFECT features an outstanding cast of actors and a great 1980s soundtrack.  The movie was marketed with the tagline of  "A BIG CHILL for Generation X" and though the movie shares some characteristics with that movie, THE LATHER EFFECT is more like a slow drain to nowhere.The plot follows a group of high school friends reunited about fifteen years after their graduation.  Valinda (Connie Britton) is selling her parents' home and holds a huge 1980s-themed party two nights before the buyers of the house are to arrive to sign the papers and officially take ownership of the home.  The movie begins the morning after the massive party and only the core group of high school friends remains at the house. The movie follows the group as they extend their reunion one day longer.  Before they leave, each person will have faced their past and in their own way moved into a more positive state of living in the present. You can't change the past, but you can change the future by how you live in the presentThe movie has an amazing talented group of actors who really bring their characters to life. Despite this, Eric Stoltz is the one member of the cast who really stands out.  He plays Mickey, a guy from down the street.  Mickey graduated years before the other people at Valinda's party and barely knew them.  He lives in a state of arrested adolescence, but it is his comments and reactions that are the heart of the movie.  His character seems like a middle-aged man trying to live like a teenager, but has more wisdom than the rest of the characters in the cast combined. However, Stoltz is basically playing the same role he played once before, Chet in Noah Baumbach's KICKING AND SCREAMING, which illustrates everything that is wrong about THE LATHER EFFECT.  Like the so-called principle discussed in the movie, everything in THE LATHER EFFECT feels like something done before, but it's not as good the second-time around and is just full of little bubbles of empty air.Besides the usual director commentary, the DVD features a few other special features including "The Making of THE LATHER EFFECT" featurette, deleted scenes, a segment with/about director Sarah Kelly entitled "The Cameron Effect", and "The Importance of Being An Earnest PA" featurette, as well as trailers for other Anchor Bay films.  Having viewed the extras I have to say I really like director & co-writer Sarah Kelly.  She seems like a person I would really enjoy working with and/or for.  I particularly enjoyed "The Cameron Effect" and "The Importance of Being An Earnest PA".  In "The Cameron Effect" Sarah gushes about Cameron Crowe and his published promise that he "might" attend a day of filming of THE LATHER EFFECT. Kelly is adorable in the segment.  "The Importance of Being An Earnest PA" features some of the PAs from THE LATHER EFFECT discussing their experiences as well as director Kelly and Eric Stoltz discussing their experiences as PAs and how invaluable it was to their careers.  PAs often get a bad rap, but the featurette illustrates how essential PAs are to the filmmaking process.

reviewText: "The Latter Effect" starts off promising enough and has a very good cast. The film though quickly falls apart due to cliched writing and direction.  The soundtrack is impressive with a nice array of 80's hits. While they are well used they are used to cover up the lack of comedy/drama rather than enhance it.Valinda (Connie Britton) brings together  a group of friends played by Ione Skye, Eric Stoltz, David Herman, Sarah Clarke, Peter Facinelli, Tate Donovan and Caitlin Keats to an 80's party designed to help her relieve the tension in her life. The results should be a mixture of comedy and pathos at missed opportunities much like "The Big Chill" but its as if "The Big Chill" were directed by John Hughes never escaping the teenage angst that was a hallmark of his films.The film has good intentions but good intentions don't make a great film. Rent it if you must see it.
summary: Light and frothy with as much substance and entertainment value
